reviews.title: Would recommend it
reviews.text: Stayed at the hotel for 3 nights and thought it was a really nice hotel. Staff were friendly and the location was great. You can get a metro directly from gare du midi (main train station) direct to madou, which is a couple of minutes walk from the hotel. The room was lovely and bright - no peeling wallpaper in sight. Bathroom was fully tiled. Breakfast served from 6:30-9:30am and had a good variety of cereals, bread, meat, cheese as well as croissants and pain au chocolat. There is also a mini-supermarket beside the metro station for those late night munchies!
We walked into the centre of town most days - about half an hour walk. Cathedral is about 15 mins away. Would definitely recommend going to see it lit up at night.

reviews.text: I just got back from a few days un Brussels at the Hotel du Congres. It's very close to the Madou stop on the metro. A very nice cabbie was able to give me directions. At first I thought the location was a bit sketchy, but it turned out to be okay. Its about a 10 minute walk before you get to some of the attractions down Rue de Royal.
I stayed at the Hotel du Congres for one night on a business trip to Brussels and found it a bit of a mixed experience.
reviews.title: Mixed feelings about the Hotel du Congres

likes.disliked: — Avoid the rooms on the main road!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The hotel was easy to get to on public transport from Brussels Midi, and was a 10 minute walk from la Grand Place. If you are staying there on a Sunday night this is important because there are no restaurants around the hotel open on a Sunday night. The hotel was clean, and my single room ingeniously designed to make the most of the compact space. For one night it was more than adequate, but it would be very cramped for a stay of more than a few nights. The bed was perfectly comfortable, and the reception staff were polite and helfpul. Breakfast was a standard continental affair - fruit, yoghurts, breads and pastries, cheese, ham etc. Again, it was nothing special, but perfectly adequate. Above all, this hotel was cheap - around £40 for the night.

Unfortunately there was also an extremely bright security light on the building opposite which shone straigh into my room, even through the curtains. reviews.title: Quircky Layout, good price

reviews.text: I've stayed there several times, because I have a regular meeting a block or so away. It's pretty basic, with small rooms as is typical of such hotels in Europe, but adequate for what it purports to be - a budget hotel in an expensive city. Breakfast is ample; there's a nice lobby and a small garden. Staff are very helpful. One thing to be careful of -- at least one of the garden rooms (502) is on the 2d floor (US style, first in Europe) with no elevator and a narrow steep stairway. Close to Madou subway stop and (at other end of street) a tram line. Good variety of restaurants a block or so away, and a small grocery store near subway stop.
reviews.title: Basic, but fine

likes.disliked: — Older/disabled travelers should be sure to get a room on the ground floor or with a lift.

reviews.text: This is one of the worst hotels I've stayed in at this price range in a city where hotels rooms are very expensive. I booked via Expedia and was expecting a room considerably better than this. Accor Group budget hotels are better quality than this. The decor of the room was tired and dated. Wallpaper was peeling off, paintwork was badly chipped. The furniture was basic with bedspreads long past their best (a lot of the stiching was coming loose). An old concertina door led to a clean bathroom, although both the toilet seat and shower cubicle doors were damaged and the basin cracked. The enamel of the shower tray was badly chipped as well. The saving grace was the breakfast, although not outstanding, was filling and tasty. I summary I would not recommend this hotel at all and would spend more time searching for a better quality establshment.
